title: A pickup’s persistent plastic pan problems
author: John Paul
bullets: A Ford F-150 owner faces repeated issues with a leaking plastic oil pan, now needing a third replacement.
Ford offers a replacement metal oil pan, but the switch would incur higher labor costs not covered by the warranty.
Ford's design challenges extend to other models, like Explorer's water pump requiring significant engine disassembly for repairs.

title: Patriots get bad news with injuries ahead of Bucs matchup
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots' Garrett Bradbury, Kayshon Boutte, and Rhamondre Stevenson missed Wednesday's practice ahead of the game against the Buccaneers.
New England rookies TreVeyon Henderson and Terrell Jennings combined for 90 rushing yards and a touchdown last week.
Bucs' key players Chris Godwin and Bucky Irving also missed practice on Wednesday due to injuries.

title: Boston youth baseball coach pleads not guilty to drug trafficking charge
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Bryan Mejia, a youth baseball coach at Boston Athletic Academy, faces a felony for trafficking over 10 grams of fentanyl.
Mejia, 31, from Mattapan, was arrested after allegedly selling fentanyl to an undercover officer on October 19.
He pleaded not guilty in Roxbury court, released on recognizance, and is due back on December 1 for a hearing.

title: Education technology company to close Boston headquarters, embrace fully remote workplace
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Cengage Group will close its Boston headquarters and offices in Detroit and Cincinnati, shifting to fully remote operations.
The company is subleasing its Boston office space and maintains its only U.S. location in Independence, Kentucky.
Cengage serves 90 million students globally and has integrated generative AI into its learning platforms.

title: What Patriots players did during their off day that impressed Mike Vrabel
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: 41 Patriots players worked out at Gillette Stadium during their off day, impressing coach Mike Vrabel.
Stefon Diggs credited the mid-season commitment to workouts for helping define the Patriots' team identity.
Despite a 7-2 record, the Patriots focus on continuous improvement rather than resting on their achievements.

title: Officials identify two killed in apparent murder-suicide in Beverly
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Becky Lynn Center, 58, and John Patrick Nesbitt, 56, were found dead in a Beverly home on Colonial Drive.
Police and officials suspect the incident was an apparent murder-suicide involving gunshot wounds.
Essex County District Attorney's Office, Beverly police, and Massachusetts State Police are investigating the case.

title: South Boston man linked to Bulger sentenced to 15 years for involvement in 1984, 1993 cold case killings
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Michael Lewis, 65, of South Boston, sentenced to 15 years for 1984 and 1993 killings linked to James 'Whitey' Bulger.
Lewis pleaded guilty to manslaughter for the deaths of Brian Watson and William Villani after murder charges were reduced.
Recording of Lewis admitting to the killings in 2020 led to the guilty plea; cases were closed after decades-old investigations.

title: Olney: Red Sox ‘well-positioned’ to try and trade for Tigers ace Tarik Skubal
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Boston Red Sox are considering a trade for Tigers pitcher Tarik Skubal, a potential 2026 Cy Young frontrunner.
Skubal, 28, led the AL in ERA and WHIP last season, making him a highly sought-after trade target.
The Red Sox have assets and fiscal flexibility to trade for and potentially retain Skubal with a long-term contract.

title: Judge temporarily halts patron saint statues in Quincy, but PETA wants to help
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: A judge temporarily blocked the installation of two patron saint statues at Quincy's public safety building last month.
PETA offered to cover costs if Quincy adds a St. Francis statue, promoting kindness to animals.
The ACLU filed a lawsuit claiming religious icons lack transparency; the city plans to appeal the ruling.

title: Bill Belichick commends Drake Maye for an ‘outstanding’ start with Patriots
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick praised Patriots QB Drake Maye's 'outstanding' season, noting his role in the team's 7-2 start.
Drake Maye, completing 74.1% of passes, ranks fifth in NFL passing yards and is third in MVP odds.
Belichick warned of the sophomore slump, comparing the Patriots' rise to the Washington Commanders' current struggles.
